comments.body:
Mock looks good but I’m finding the wording of the AC and example hard to digest.

As I understand the intent, it’s that

(1) in desktop overview and interactive view, the 8dp spacing is between each level A task and runs straight down to the lower levels. It continues just to separate the level A task descendants from each other even as the user pans to the lower levels of the task hierarchy.

(2) in mobile, the UX is different (the level-by-level expansion/contraction) and the 8dp gutter is also different \- it exists between the parent task “stubs” currently visible on the left hand side of the screen and separates their children and grandchildren from each other. As the user zooms lower in the hierarchy, the 8dp gutter adjusts so that it now separates the new just-visible-on-the-left tasks.

[~JeromyH] is that how you see it?
Decided in planning today just to tackle the “level A separation” problem \- other issues in mobile will be tackled later

[~JeromyH] [~graeme.johnston] Have updated the AC in this a little in light of implementation.

Previoius AC didn't say if both OV and IV were to be affected and what the dps should be for minimap so we have taken the following view…

8dp is being applied to overview and interactive and 4dp is being applied to minimap.

fields.description:
As a Juralio developer, I want confidence that the e2e tests will reliably report actual failures in our code.
Currently, the e2e tests covering datetime consistency are intermittently failing, leading to failed builds that shouldn't be failing. Locally, these tests run fine, but on our build agents, can sometimes slow down and fail. This is (probably) because of the intensive usage of the date picker components during setup for these tests.

AC:

# Investigate
# Split up the consistency tests into smaller batches.

NOTE: Observed stale object exception in consistency tests which may contribute to failures. Keep an eye on server logs when attempting to fix the build.

fields.description:
Template tasks in each sibling group should be restricted to 8 in order to ensure a good mobile experience and to encourage task breakdown into comprehensible clusters. This should work in the same way as for task map in projects.

AC:

# In a template, there are a maximum of 8 tasks
## at level A
## within each sibling group of subtasks
# UI is the same as in project task map.
## Show error message when task has 8 subtasks or 8 level A tasks
## Disable Create button when an error message is shown
# It is not possible to add more than 8 tasks via the API
fields.summary: Restrict template tasks to 8 sub tasks

comments.body:
On sorting, yes let’s discuss. Some initial thoughts on sensible basic rules

* for J-numbers, prioritise complete match over partial match e.g. if I type 1234 then results should be ordered something like \(i) J1234 (ii) J12345 (iii) J234
* prioritise things that appear in the task name or J-number fields over things that appear just in the description

But of course let’s keep it simple as post-MVP I expect we’ll substitute something a bit more sophisticated (rather than building it ourselves)

[~jieming.liu] We need to be clearer on what we are are going to be displaying as a search result for this PBI from the mock. Mock displays name, description, date (what date field?) and coloured reference number losenge. Is the plan to do all of those in this PBI?

fields.description:
AC:

# When performing search in project, user can search tasks whose description include the search term.
# The result list displays task description below the task name
## If a task has no description, then its description is not displayed in the result list.

Dev note: Remove old e2e tests that will search on 'notice board text'

See mocks @ [https://gallery.io/projects/MCHbtQVoQ2HCZSEMzNlrtRQC/files/MCEJu8Y2hyDScYbfNIF6nCI6wA0NAV1mMcM]

comments.body:
@Devs 
Suggest copying the logic for 'searchableNoticeboardText'. I don't remember why we need searching on a non-auditable field but I suppose there was a performance issue.

My question here is: would the preview text in the search results show the words immediately before and after the search hit, e.g. if I search for “beanstalk” does the preview read “… a wonderful beanstalk, strong and tall…” or does it read “Once upon a time, there was a little boy…”
[~accountid:557058:0a6b3dce-530b-4ba8-b3fb-bde9c85c0e16] I think we discussed this with Jeromy and we were going to do the latter for now. More work would be needed to highlight the matched text.
[~accountid:557058:ee760046-443e-4cb3-9635-27dc3ae63b42] OK \- thank you.
[~accountid:557058:2b5732b1-fde7-4d69-a7bc-d266b299ee44] IIRC the field was added to stop HTML formatting messing up the text matching.

comments.body:
@Devs
We need a separate URL to point the same controller (ProjectContentSearchController). The URL should not include 'project_id'. Have a look at ProjectContentSearchController -> ProjectContentSearchService -> ProjectContentSearchFilter. 'Should' be a small change. :)
Don’t know if this is feasible for MVP, but each search result in this scenario really ought to show the project, otherwise it’s not very useful…

[~accountid:557058:0a6b3dce-530b-4ba8-b3fb-bde9c85c0e16] [~accountid:5b2b691c02cfea1ba6414735] [~accountid:5b199c50b0d76456f36dba36] The search api returns project name, we just need to figure out the display position.

Issue split into:
|JUR-12062|Display project name in search results|
